question_details.title: Will Apple allow side-loading or other app stores on their iPhones before 2026? (United States)
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2023-02-19 15:55:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/14135). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

On 14 September 2022 the [Regulation 2022/1925 on contestable and fair markets in the digital sector (better known as the Digital Markets Act or DMA) was adopted](https://www.simmons-simmons.com/en/publications/cl5qyuy0o1h0y0a59y4osbiqx/digital-markets-act-is-adopted). Its primary aim are issues regarding [contestability and fairness in the digital economy](https://www.whitecase.com/insight-alert/digital-markets-act-dma-goes-live), with a focus on prohibitions and obligations imposed upon Big Tech. The DMA impacts a wide variety of companies such as Amazon, Google, or Apple, with an anticipated enforcement date of March 2024.

The [Financial Times](https://www.ft.com/content/0c2d56f7-a402-45ea-8aa6-0e05e6260b68) reported that the DMA represents the “biggest threat to [Apple’s] control over its operating system in 15 years”. 

> Apple is laying the groundwork to comply with tough new EU rules that will allow iPhone users to pick apps from beyond its own App Store, as developers seek to skirt the up to 30 per cent fee imposed by the US tech giant.

This comes against the backdrop of Apple’s legal fight with Fortnite maker Epic Games about Epic’s own app store that resulted in Apple pulling Fortnite from their App Store. The DMA may make it illegal for Apple to prohibit other app stores on their phones.

However, as the [Financial Times]( https://www.ft.com/content/0c2d56f7-a402-45ea-8aa6-0e05e6260b68) reports, a potential workaround for Apple could be “sideloading”, where users are able to install software directly via a browser (without using rival app stores). 

While the DMA only applies to the EU, there is also the possibility of a regulatory spill-over to other jurisdictions.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":14135,"question_id":14137}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'United States'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

This question will resolve as **Yes** if there are credible media reports that either (i) sideloading is straightforwardly possible on iPhones without the need to circumvent Apple's rules or (ii) non-Apple app stores are available on the iPhone before January 1, 2026. 

This question will resolve as **No** if no such credible media reports exist before January 1, 2026

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Apple challenges EU digital markets act in biggest antitrust court test**
Apple Inc. is mounting the most significant legal challenge to the European Union's Digital Markets Act (DMA), arguing that the law imposes 'hugely onerous and intrusive burdens' that conflict with its rights in the EU marketplace. Apple's lawyer, Daniel Beard, presented three main objections before the General Court in Luxembourg: first, that interoperability requirements forcing iPhone services to work with rival hardware threaten user privacy, security, and intellectual property; second, that the App Store should not be subject to DMA rules because it does not constitute a 'single service' under the law's definition; and third, that the EU's attempt to investigate iMessage under the DMA was unjustified, as it does not directly generate revenue. EU Commission lawyer Paul-John Loewenthal countered that Apple's 'absolute control' over the iPhone ecosystem has enabled 'supernormal profits' and created an uneven playing field, locking in over a third of European smartphone users. The DMA, enacted in 2023, targets dominant digital platforms with strict obligations. Apple is also challenging a €500 million ($581 million) fine related to the App Store, following a previous €1.8 billion antitrust penalty for similar conduct. Other tech giants, including Google, Microsoft, Amazon, Meta, ByteDance, and Booking Holdings, have also been affected. Apple’s case is the most direct assault on the DMA’s enforcement, following an earlier setback for ByteDance over TikTok. The EU has issued over €9.5 billion in fines against Google and ordered Apple to pay €13 billion in back taxes to Ireland.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 21, 2025 05:40 PM
Source:[Business Standard](https://www.business-standard.com/world-news/apple-challenges-eu-digital-markets-act-in-biggest-antitrust-court-test-125102100940_1.html)

**Apple Challenges EU Digital Markets Act at European Court**
Apple has filed a formal complaint before the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg against the EU's Digital Markets Act (DMA), according to Bloomberg. Apple's legal team criticized the DMA rules as excessively burdensome, specifically opposing three provisions: mandatory interoperability with third-party hardware, inclusion of the App Store under DMA regulations, and an ongoing investigation into the iMessage messaging service. In response, the European Commission's legal representative argued that Apple has generated above-average profits through exclusive control of the iPhone ecosystem and has locked in more than one-third of European smartphone users. The dispute has a long history: in April 2025, Apple was fined €500 million for allegedly violating DMA rules, following a prior €1.8 billion penalty for anti-competitive behavior related to music streaming apps. While other tech giants—including Google, Microsoft, Amazon, Meta, ByteDance, and Booking Holdings—are also subject to the DMA, Apple's complaint is considered the most aggressive legal challenge to date. ByteDance's similar attempt to challenge TikTok’s inclusion under the DMA had previously failed. The article notes the presence of affiliate links, which may generate a small commission for the publisher if readers make purchases, though these do not affect pricing or reporting integrity.

**Apple's walled garden faces European court challenge to its digital empire**
Apple faced the European Commission in a high-stakes hearing in Luxembourg on October 21, 2025, challenging its designation as a 'gatekeeper' under the EU's Digital Markets Act (DMA), a law designed to prevent tech giants from monopolizing digital ecosystems. **Apple and Meta Near Breakthrough Deal with EU to Avoid Massive Fines**
Apple and Meta are on the verge of reaching a landmark agreement with the European Commission to resolve months-long regulatory disputes under the EU's Digital Markets Act (DMA). According to reports by the Financial Times, Apple has agreed to modify App Store rules, including removing restrictions on steering users to external payment options and introducing a new fee structure: a 5% commission on purchases outside the App Store and a 'Core Technology Fee' for each annual app download exceeding one million installations. Although the deal has not yet been formally approved by Brussels, sources cited by FT indicate 'cautious optimism.' The DMA and Digital Services Act (DSA) are the two pillars of the EU’s new digital regulatory framework. The DMA targets gatekeepers like Apple, Meta, Google, and Amazon by mandating fair competition, interoperability, and transparency—requiring Apple to allow sideloading and Meta to offer real privacy choices. The DSA focuses on platform accountability for user-generated content, requiring rapid removal of illegal content, greater algorithmic transparency, and stronger consumer protection.

**Europe's Digital Markets Act: Conflict and Confusion**
The European Union's Digital Markets Act (DMA), enacted three years ago, aims to regulate dominant tech 'gatekeepers'—primarily American companies—by requiring structural changes to promote competition. Under the DMA, Apple must reduce app store fees and allow third-party access to iOS; Google must stop favoring its own services in search; and Meta may need to offer a free, ad-free service. European regulators have already fined Apple and Meta hundreds of millions of euros and are preparing to penalize Google for noncompliance. The law has sparked transatlantic tensions: U.S. tech firms argue that DMA-mandated changes degrade product quality, compromise privacy and security, and delay European product launches. Apple delayed Live Translation and blocked iPhone Mirroring due to security concerns, while Google’s inability to link directly to its Maps and travel sites has reportedly caused up to €114 billion in revenue losses, according to Alphabet’s lawyer Oliver Bethell. Critics from both sides highlight enforcement gaps: competitors like Spotify claim Apple’s compliance measures undermine the DMA’s goal of consumer choice, while consumer groups such as BEUC call for faster enforcement. The European Commission is evaluating the DMA’s effectiveness, with a recent consultation closing in September 2025. Despite calls from Apple and Google for repeal or reform, the Commission is likely to expand the law’s scope to include cloud computing and AI services. Globally, the DMA has inspired similar laws in Japan, the UK, and other jurisdictions. Although the U.S. has not passed comparable legislation, federal antitrust actions against Apple, Amazon, Meta, and Google continue, with some cases seeking corporate breakup. The DMA enables faster regulatory action than traditional antitrust, but the required product changes are costly—hundreds of thousands of engineering hours have been spent—and often degrade user experience. The future remains uncertain: all three major tech firms are appealing fines and rulings to the European Court of Justice. Potential solutions include establishing an independent enforcement agency and expanding the DMA to cover AI and cloud services. The DMA continues to generate significant political, economic, and legal tension.

**EU Defends Digital Markets Act Against Apple Criticism**
The European Union rejected Apple’s request to repeal the Digital Markets Act (DMA), a law that entered force last year to curb abuses by dominant tech firms. Apple, which has opposed the DMA since its launch, argued that the regulation has degraded the services it offers and exposed users to new risks. In an official contribution to a Commission consultation, Apple said the DMA should be "abrogated and replaced by a more suitable legislative text" and proposed a separate regulatory agency to enforce the rules. The EU, however, categorically denied any intention to repeal the DMA. A Commission spokesperson, Thomas Regnier, said the EU was "not surprised by Apple’s lobbying arguments" and that the company had "continually contested every aspect of the DMA since its entry into force". Apple also claimed the DMA forces it to restrict features on its products, citing the removal of the live‑translation function from the newly released AirPods Pro 3 and the inability to open its devices to third‑party app stores or alternative payment systems. The company claims the Commission has "treated the DMA as a weapon, adopting an adversarial stance solely against Apple," a statement that Apple says is "totally inappropriate for this regulatory framework." The DMA review is scheduled for completion by May 2026, with subsequent reviews every three years.

**Apple Faces €500 Million Fine Over Sideloading Rules Under EU Digital Markets Act**
Apple is currently fighting a €500 million fine imposed by Brussels for allegedly restricting developers from informing users about alternatives outside the App Store, a violation of the EU Digital Markets Act (DMA). The DMA requires app creators to direct consumers toward external purchasing options, thereby loosening Apple’s control over digital sales. The fine, announced on 29 August 2025, follows Apple’s refusal to allow sideloading—installing apps from third‑party stores—which the DMA now permits. Apple has described the penalty as 'sin precedentes' and the required changes as 'ilegales', arguing that Brussels oversteps its authority. The legal battle is expected to last years, with developers exploring new distribution channels while raising concerns about security and visibility. The case illustrates the broader tension between EU regulation and tech giants, as the DMA seeks to increase competition but also introduces risks such as fraud and cyber‑attacks if alternative stores are not properly managed.

**Powerful EU Rules Regulating Tech and Annoying Trump: Orange News**
The article reports that U.S. President Donald Trump has strongly criticized the European Union’s regulatory framework for the tech sector, threatening tariffs and export restrictions. It explains that the EU possesses the most powerful legal arsenal for digital regulation, having already imposed hefty fines on U.S. tech giants such as Meta and Apple. Brussels has refused to relax its two flagship laws – the Digital Services Act (DSA) and the Digital Markets Act (DMA) – in trade negotiations with the United States.

The DSA aims to protect European users by imposing obligations on platforms, including:
- establishing a reporting system for problematic content;
- acting "promptement" to remove illicit content;
- banning targeted advertising to minors.
Large platforms (X, TikTok, Meta, Apple, Google) face additional rules: they must assess risks related to illegal content, privacy, freedom of expression, health and public safety, and implement mitigation measures such as content moderation. They must also provide regulators and approved researchers with algorithmic access for compliance checks. Violations can lead to fines of up to 6 % of annual turnover, and repeated serious breaches may result in a ban from operating in Europe.

The DMA seeks to end the dominant‑position abuse of tech giants (Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon, Microsoft) to protect startups and improve consumer choice. Key provisions include:
- allowing users to uninstall pre‑installed services (browsers, maps, weather) and choose alternative app stores;
- prohibiting cross‑platform data aggregation for targeted advertising without user consent.
The European Commission, with a team of about a hundred experts, holds enforcement power. Penalties can reach 10 % of global turnover, and 20 % for repeat offenders.

The article quotes the DSA’s requirement for platforms to act "promptement" and highlights the EU’s willingness to impose substantial fines, underscoring the tension between U.S. tech firms and European regulators.

summary:
Across a diverse array of expert perspectives—including US tech regulation and antitrust law, mobile software development, technology policy, and business strategy—there is near-unanimous consensus that Apple will NOT allow sideloading or other app stores on iPhones in the United States before January 1, 2026. All experts note that, although Apple's compliance with the EU’s Digital Markets Act (DMA) has enabled sideloading and alternative app stores in Europe, Apple has explicitly geo-fenced these changes and vigorously resisted extending them to other regions, especially the US. 

Key points include:
- The regulatory environment in the US is far less forceful than in the EU; no law equivalent to the DMA is in place or imminent, and US antitrust actions have so far focused on other App Store practices (such as payment systems and anti-steering rules), not on mandating sideloading or alternative app stores.
- Apple has a strong financial and strategic incentive to maintain its closed ecosystem in the US, given the substantial revenue and competitive advantage derived from control over app distribution.
- Ongoing court cases and legislative efforts in the US are moving slowly, with no credible sign of a regulatory or legal mandate that would force Apple to comply before the January 2026 deadline.
- While some tail risk exists (e.g., a sudden court order or new legislation), base rates for such a rapid, dramatic shift in the US are exceedingly low.
- The technical capability for sideloading is now proven (from EU compliance), but Apple shows no willingness to voluntarily enable it in the US absent direct compulsion.

Quantitative forecasts range from 1% to 3%, reflecting only a minimal nonzero probability for a major, unforeseeable legal or regulatory event. The weight of evidence and all plausible scenarios indicate that Apple’s status quo policy will hold in the US through at least the end of 2025.
